summary: Email correspondence between Assistant U.S. Attorney Christian Everdell and defense attorney Laura Menninger regarding discovery issues in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The emails discuss the production of thousands of images from Epstein's devices, the de-designation of 'Highly Confidential' materials, logistical arrangements for reviewing evidence in Colorado, and technical problems with accessing discovery materials.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Prosecutor in the Southern District of New York handling discovery production and logistics for the government in the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Defense counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell, raising numerous discovery deficiencies and requesting access to evidence including images from Epstein's devices.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the Maxwell case, whose order (Dkt. No. 322) is referenced as requiring a meet and confer.

events.title: Evidence Review in New York
events.description: Defense counsel traveled to New York to review evidence, including highly confidential materials on hard drives.

events.title: FBI Report on Digital Evidence
events.description: FBI report indicating approximately 33,747 'Highly Confidential' images and 895 HC videos identified from CART-processed evidence from Epstein's devices.

locations: 1 St. Plaza New York, NY 10007 (SDNY office)
Epstein's private island (referenced in context of 3D scan)
keyFacts: The FBI had approximately 40,000 images extracted from CDs seized from Epstein's New York residence, with thousands designated as 'Highly Confidential' due to nudity.
A discrepancy existed between the government's initial estimate of 2,100 nude images from Epstein's devices and an FBI report indicating approximately 33,747 HC images and 895 HC videos.
The defense requested and arranged for review of evidence (hard drives and boots) to be relocated to the FBI field office in Colorado for easier access.
Significant technical problems plagued the discovery process, with thousands of images unreadable due to corrupt files, missing metadata, and incompatible file formats.

The protective order defined 'Highly Confidential' material broadly to include any nude, partially-nude, or sexualized images, not limited to child pornography, restricting defense access to government-controlled review only.
